p.text: [Div 3 insrt Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 9 June 2006]
The provisions of this Division comprise uniform rules developed under the auspices of the Australian Council of Chief Justices.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.18] r 25.18 Interpretation (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Interpretation (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 1 )

p.text: In this Division:
means an applicant for a search order.
includes described generally whether by reference to a class or otherwise.
includes a vehicle or vessel of any kind.
means a person against whom a search order is sought or made.
has the meaning given by rule 25.19 .
In any notice of motion for a search order, a party should be referred to by the appropriate expression prescribed by rule 18.3 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.19] r 25.19 Search order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Search order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 2 )

p.text: The court may make an order (a search order), in any proceeding or in anticipation of any proceeding in the court, with or without notice to the respondent, for the purpose of securing or preserving evidence and requiring a respondent to permit persons to enter premises for the purpose of securing the preservation of evidence which is or may be relevant to an issue in the proceeding or anticipated proceeding.

An applicant for a search order usually applies exÂ parte and before service of originating process. Secrecy and the lack of warning to the respondent is usually an important aspect of the order. An application for a freezing order should be made by motion and should comply with the substance of the requirements contained in Practice Note SC Gen 13. The affidavits in support of an application for a search order should include the following information:
a description of the things or category of things in relation to which the order is sought;
the address or location of any premises in relation to which the order is sought and whether they are private or business premises;
why the order is sought, including why there is a real possibility that the things to be searched for will be destroyed or otherwise made unavailable for use in evidence unless the order is made;
the prejudice, loss or damage likely to be suffered by the applicant if the order is not made;
the name, address, firm and commercial litigation experience of an independent solicitor, who consents to being appointed to serve the order, supervise its execution; and

if the premises to be searched are or include residential premises, whether or not the applicant believes that the only occupant is likely to be a female, a child under the age of 18, a vulnerable person or any combination of one or more of these persons.

The power conferred by the present rule is expressly directed towards ensuring the availability of evidence to determine proceedings in the court. The power is based upon the need to protect the court’s ability to do justice between the parties: see Anton Piller KG v Manufacturing Processes Ltd [1976] Ch 55; [1976] 1 All ER 779Â ; EMI Ltd v Pandit [1975] 1 All ER 418; [1975] 1 WLR 302Â ; ExÂ parte Island Records Ltd [1978] Ch 122; [1978] 3 All ER 824Â . The “Anton Piller” search order is a form of compulsory discovery characteristically used in cases involving breach of copyright or other intellectual property rights. Such an order directs the defendant to permit appointed persons to enter premises and seize evidence material to the plaintiff’s claim: see Anton Piller KG v Manufacturing Processes Ltd, above; EMI Ltd v Pandit, above; ExÂ parte Island Records Ltd, above; Cummings v 2KY Broadcasters Pty Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 246; (1981) 51 FLR 121Â Â (refusal of order to produce recording of allegedly defamatory broadcast); Polygram Records Pty Ltd v Monash Records (Australia) Pty Ltd (1985) 10 FCR 332; 72 ALR 35Â Â (alleged infringement of copyright in sound recordings — order made); Warman International Ltd v Envirotech Aust Pty Ltd (1986) 11 FCR 478; 67 ALR 253Â Â (application to restrain breach of copyright in industrial design drawings); Chrysalis Records Ltd v Vere (1982) 43 ALR 440; 65 FLR 422Â ; Emanuel v Emanuel [1982] 2 All ER 342; [1982] 1 WLR 669Â .

An applicant who applies for a search order without notice to the persons affected is subject to the same disclosure obligations as those that apply to an applicant for a freezing order: see Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [20] and [25.11.20] . And, just as in the case of applications for ex parte injunctions, a search order applicant must make full and frank disclosure to the court of all material circumstances. Breach of that obligation may result in the court discharging the order (Thermax v Schott Industrial Glass Ltd [1981] FSR 289Â ) and requiring the plaintiff to honour its undertaking as to damages: Digital Equipment Corp v Darkcrest Ltd [1984] Ch 512; [1984] 3 WLR 617Â ; Columbia Pictures Industries Inc v Robinson [1987] Ch 38; [1986] 3 All ER 338Â . The disclosure obligation includes not only matters that tend to reveal a defence to the applicant’s claim but also matters relating to the adequacy of the applicant’s undertaking as to damages: see SC Gen 13 at [19] and [20]. The amplitude of the disclosure obligation has prompted the judicial observation that affidavits in support of search orders should “err on the side of excessive disclosure”: Columbia Pictures Industries Inc v Robinson [1987] Ch 38 at 77; [1986] 3 All ER 338Â per Scott J.

Any search order should be supported by the applicant’s undertaking as to damages. Security may be required to support the undertaking: see further [25.8.5] , [25.8.10] and Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [18] and [19].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.20] r 25.20 Requirements for grant of search order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Requirements for grant of search order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 3 )

p.text: The court may make a search order if the court is satisfied that:
an applicant seeking the order has a strong prima facie case on an accrued cause of action, and
the potential or actual loss or damage to the applicant will be serious if the search order is not made, and
there is sufficient evidence in relation to a respondent that:
the respondent possesses important evidentiary material, and
there is a real possibility that the respondent might destroy such material or cause it to be unavailable for use in evidence in a proceeding or anticipated proceeding before the court.

level.toc-caption: [25.20.5] Strong prima facie case on an accrued cause of action

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.20.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 25.14(1), rÂ 25.20.

heading.title: Strong prima facie case on an accrued cause of action

p.text: The threshold criterion for making a search order is that the applicant establish a “strong prima facie case” on an accrued cause of action. This expression differs from the familiar requirements of a “triable issue” (relating to summary judgment: see [13.1.5] and [13.1.10] ) and a “good arguable case” (relating to freezing orders: see [25.14.5] ). The meaning of the expression “prima facie case” has been discussed in cases related to those contexts: see Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560Â ; Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428Â ; Hyde v Agar (1998) 45 NSWLR 487 at 503–6; BC9805415Â ; Patterson v BTR Engineering (Aust) Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 319Â . There may be room to debate whether, in those contexts, the differences of expression really indicate materially different criteria: see [25.1.35] . However, there is a significant, and apparently deliberate, departure from the wording from rÂ 25.14(1) of the UCPR and the actual requirement in rÂ 25.20 of the UCPR is that the applicant satisfy the court it has a “strong prima facie case”. This change suggests that an applicant for a search order must do more than establish an “arguable” case and must affirmatively satisfy the court that, on the basis of the presently available information, it has a genuine likelihood of succeeding on its substantive claim in the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [25.20.10] Real possibility of destruction of evidence

heading.title: Real possibility of destruction of evidence

p.text: The principal criterion for the exercise of the power to make a search order under the present rules is the court’s satisfaction there is a “real possibilty” of the unavailability of evidence material to the proper determination of the applicant’s accrued cause of action. The emphasis on the existence of a “real possibility” is intended to highlight the exceptional nature of the discretionary power and to counsel against its improper use to supplant the established procedures governing the grant of interlocutory injunctive relief: Rank Film Distributors Ltd v Video Information Centre [1982] AC 380 at 439; [1981] 2 All ER 76Â ; Simsek v MacPhee (Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs) (1982) 148 CLR 636 at 641; 40 ALR 61 at 65; BC8200059Â ; Columbia Pictures Industries Inc v Robinson [1987] Ch 38; [1986] 3 All ER 338Â ; Cokinos v Walker [2007] NSWSC 1040; BC200707973Â (ex parte application refused — subsequently granted after contested hearing); Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [4].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.21] r 25.21 Jurisdiction (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 4 )

p.text: Nothing in this Division diminishes the inherent, implied or statutory jurisdiction of the court to make a search order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.22] r 25.22 Terms of search order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Terms of search order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 5 )

p.text: A search order may direct each person who is named or described in the order:
to permit, or arrange to permit, such other persons as are named or described in the order:
to enter premises specified in the order, and
to take any steps that are in accordance with the terms of the order, and
to provide, or arrange to provide, such other persons named or described in the order with any information, thing or service described in the order, and
to allow such other persons named or described in the order to take and retain in their custody any thing described in the order, and
not to disclose any information about the order, for up to 3 days after the date on which the order was served, except for the purposes of obtaining legal advice or legal representation, and
to do or refrain from doing any act as the court considers appropriate.
Without limiting the generality of subrule (1)(a)(ii), the steps that may be taken in relation to a thing specified in a search order include:
searching for, inspecting or removing the thing, and
making or obtaining a record of the thing or any information it may contain.
A search order may contain such other provisions as the court considers appropriate.
In subrule (2):
includes a copy, photograph, film or sample.

level.toc-caption: [25.22.5] Form of search order — Practice Notes

heading.title: Form of search order — Practice Notes

p.text: The Practice Note outlines the general requirements when a search order application is made: Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [8]. An appropriate form of search order is set out in Practice Note SC Gen 13. Variations of the typical Anton Piller order may also extend to requiring a defendant to disclose information and produce documents: Gates v Swift (1982) RPC 339; Bankers Trust Co v Shapira [1980] 3 All ER 353; [1980] 1 WLR 1274Â ; AJ Bekhor & Co Ltd v Bilton [1981] QB 923; [1981] 2 All ER 565Â ; CBS United Kingdom Ltd v Lambert [1983] Ch 37; [1982] 3 All ER 237Â ; British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417Â ; RCA Corporation v Reddington Rare Records [1975] 1 All ER 38; [1974] FSR 509Â ; including requiring the production of computer printouts for inspection by the plaintiff: Gates v Swift, above. Orders of this kind are made only in special circumstances and particular caution is required where the disclosure ordered concerns confidential matters, such as the names and addresses of the defendant’s customers: Sega Enterprises Ltd v Alca Electronics [1982] FSR 516Â ; Golf Lynx v Golf Scene Pty Ltd (1984) 59 ALR 343; Â AIPC Â¶90-140Â .

Examples of search orders are provided in Jemella Australia Pty Ltd v Internet Marketing Pty Ltd (2008) 75 IPR 59; [2008] FCA 13; BC200800045Â ; Jemalla Australia Pty Ltd v Young [2008] FCA 394; BC200801950Â ; Jemalla Australia Pty Ltd v Young (No 2) [2008] FCA 396; BC200801951Â (all involving the grant of a search order in relation to alleged counterfeit products — prima facie case of breach of trade mark, potential for actual loss or damage and a real possibility that the incriminating products would be destroyed).

A search order will name and describe the persons permitted to enter the premises and to search for, inspect, copy and remove the things described in the order: Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [4]. The authorised search party must include an independent solicitor and a solicitor representing the applicant. It may also include an independent computer expert and a person able to identify things being searched for, if there are likely to be difficulties of identification. The search party should not include the applicant or directors, officers, employees or partners of the applicant: Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [6].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.23] r 25.23 Independent solicitors (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Independent solicitors (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 6 )

p.text: If the court makes a search order, the court must appoint one or more solicitors, each of whom is independent of the applicant’s solicitors (the independent solicitors), to supervise the execution of the order, and to do such other things in relation to the order as the court considers appropriate.

The court may appoint an independent solicitor to supervise execution of the order at any one or more premises, and a different independent solicitor or solicitors to supervise execution of the order at other premises, with each independent solicitor having power to do such other things in relation to the order as the court considers appropriate.

level.toc-caption: [25.23.5] Custody of and access to documents

heading.title: Custody of and access to documents

p.text: The court must appoint an independent solicitor who is responsible for the custody of all the things removed from the respondent’s premises pursuant to the order. Anything removed from the premises must be available to be brought to court for the hearing on the return day of the application. At the hearing the independent solicitor may be required to release material in their custody: see Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [11]. The applicant is not ordinarily permitted to inspect things removed from the premises or copies of them or to be given information about them by members of the search party: Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [12]. At the inter partes hearing of the application on the return day the court will consider what is to happen to any things removed from the premises or copies which have been made: Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [17].

The responsibilities of the independent solicitor are set out in Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [11]; and discussed in Metso Minerals (Australia) Ltd v Kalra (No 3) [2008] FCA 1201; BC200807350 at [15]Â ; Microsoft Corp v Goodview Electronics Pty Ltd (1999) 46 IPR 159; [1999] FCA 754; BC9903069 at [27]–[30]Â (minutes of order did not provide for the appointment of an independent solicitor to serve and supervise the execution of the order — it is desirable for a supervising solicitor, a neutral appointee of the court, to be appointed); Universal Thermosensors Ltd v Hibben [1992] 3 All ER 257; [1992] 1 WLR 840 at 861Â .

The independent solicitor must give any appropriate undertaking required by the court: Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [18]. The usual undertakings to be given by the independent solicitor are set out in Sch B to the Practice Note.

If residential premises are to be searched and are only occupied by women, children or vulnerable persons, the court will consider whether the independent solicitor (or someone else in the search party) should be a woman or a person capable of alleviating any relevant vulnerability: Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [15].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.24] r 25.24 Costs (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Costs (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25B, rule 7 )

p.text: The court may make any order as to costs that it considers appropriate in relation to an order made under this Division.
Without limiting the generality of subrule (1), an order as to costs includes an order as to the costs of any person affected by a search order.
The applicant’s solicitor must undertake to pay the reasonable costs and disbursements of the independent solicitor and any independent computer expert: see Practice Note SC Gen 13 at [10].
